text:
Welcome to another
episode of Managing

Through Crisis, the series where
we have Harvard Business School

faculty sharing their
insights about how leaders
can manage in difficult times.

Today my guest is Willy
Shih, Professor Willy Shih.

He's an expert in supply
chain, and supply chain

is all of a sudden
headline news again,
it has been for quite some time.
Willy, welcome.
Well, thank you, Brian.
I'm glad to join you here today.

So you and I had a conversation
just a couple of years

ago that's going
to probably sound

a little bit similar
to where we are today.

And we actually
launched this series

when COVID was just starting
to really pick up steam,

and we launched
it because we knew

people were looking
for ideas and insights

about how to manage in this new
unexpected crisis that we had.

I wish that two years later we
weren't having the same sort
of conversation, but we are.

The pandemic is still
with us, and now we're

seeing all this ripple effect
of things that have happened
as a result of the pandemic.

So I think people
are going to really

be interested in hearing
what you have to say,

and I'm going to start by
focusing on a topic that
is definitely headline news.

Two years ago it was toilet
paper, today it's baby formula.

What's going on
with baby formula?

Well Brian, I think there
are a couple of things.

First of all, obviously
we had this shutdown

of the Abbott Nutrition
plant in Michigan,

which took out a significant
percentage of the US capacity

for making baby formula,
particularly some

of the lower-volume
SKUs for children who
had particular nutrition needs.

And whenever you take
out that much capacity

in a market that was
already stressed,

then you have a
supply shock, which

is what we're going
through right now.
I think-- yeah, go ahead.

And I would say the other thing
is, the infant formula supply

chain was already stressed
by the same kinds of problems
that other products are facing.

Difficulty in getting
transportation,

difficulty in getting
workforce, difficulty

in getting warehouse
space, difficulty
in getting raw materials.

So we were already
in a situation

where there have been so
many disruptions across so

many supply chains that then you
have the shutdown, and boom, it
just propagates everywhere.

So we've heard a lot
about the shutdown.

We're hearing now that
they're going to be
able to get back up online--
Abbott is.

But we're hearing it's
going to take maybe weeks

or months for that
to find its way back

into some level of
normalcy within the system.

Can you explain
to our viewers why

it takes so long once they
start back up for this
to solve itself?

Well, once you
start up production,

then you have to manufacture
the product obviously,

and then you have to go through
the whole distribution network.

And distribution
in this case means

replenishing a lot of stocks
in warehouses and distribution

centers that have been
depleted by demand.
So it's just like you emptied--

you emptied the tub that was
filled with all this stuff

and it's going to take a
while to fill it back up.

So that means what
we'll see is we'll

see the shortages starting
to be relieved in some areas

faster than others,
but you have to fill up

that whole distribution
chain again.
Yeah.

Willy, I would venture to
guess that a couple of years

ago before the pandemic
hit, most people

didn't think about
supply chain at all.

It wasn't part of
their consciousness,

because everything we need
was always there for us.

But I think everybody knows
about supply chain now.

And I'm wondering,
do you think we've

learned anything in the
past couple of years

about the vulnerability
of the supply chain
across pretty much all sectors?

Well Brian, I think we've
learned a couple of things.

One is how
interconnected things are

and how often things
are interdependent.

So for example, the automakers
learned this big time

when they were caught
with a chip shortage

and they had canceled
their orders early

on when their demand had fallen
off a cliff like in April,
May of 2020.

But when they went
to reorder chips,

they found out a lot of that
manufacturing capacity way down

in the supply chain had been
picked up by somebody else,

so now all of a sudden
their lead times

for them was much longer
than they ever anticipated.

So that first lesson
was how sometimes

way down in the
supply chain, I may

share a supplier with
somebody that I didn't know.

And the other thing, I think,
we've learned is how this--

supply chains have
been really optimized

for economic efficiency, and
that's not the same thing
as resilience, necessarily.

So people maybe didn't
carry as much inventory

as would have been
helpful to obviate
some of these shortages.

And a lot of that has
been driven by cost.

So maybe we didn't
carry as much inventory.

Oftentimes people didn't
have as much slack capacity
as they might like to have.

Oftentimes we've also seen a
concentration of production
in relatively few centers.

Meatpacking was a great
example of this early

in the pandemic where
we suddenly discovered

that a lot of the meatpacking
capacity in this country

had been consolidated
into large slaughterhouses

rather than a lot of small
ones that were geographically
distributed.

And as a consequence of that,
when one of them goes out,
you remove a lot of capacity.

That's sort of the same issue
with the infant formula now,

is like there aren't
that many plants,

they don't have a lot
of slack capacity,

you take out a chunk
of that capacity

and then you feel
it very quickly.
Yeah.

So it's safe to say that
maybe some of the assumptions

that we've made in the past are
going to change going forward.

And I wonder if one of those
things that might be impacted

is the emphasis on the
global supply chain.

Do you think that we'll start to
see some firms in the US moving

away from globalization
and trying

to concentrate more things
regionally close to where they
are?

Well, I think every firm that
is dependent on production

that's dispersed
around the world,

every firm is talking
about it right now.

It's easier said than done,
because a lot of the reasons we

have dependencies
on manufacturing

in low-cost countries, is
because we're able to produce
products for much less money.

So when we move
production, for example,

from a high-cost
country like the US

to a low-cost country like
China, the cost of the move
was paid for by the savings.

The cost of the
move would be things

like setting up a factory,
training a workforce,

moving your suppliers
in, and things like that.

And the cost savings
paid for all of that.

And that works when you're
going from a high-cost country
to a low-cost country.

When you're going from
a low-cost country

to a high-cost
country, that doesn't
work quite the same way.

So then you're confronted
with higher costs.

And in the current
inflation environment,
that's a tough one.

But everybody is
looking at that.

I think one of--
among the big changes

have been just the much
higher cost of moving goods
on the water, ocean shipping.

90% of all
internationally-traded goods

move on the water, and that
has gotten much, much more
expensive.

So now that changes the equation
of how tradable is this good?
Where should I manufacture it?
That's one thing.

Another thing that
I think is really--

is just coming up
really fast, and that

is the challenges of
doing business in China,

it's gotten a lot
harder especially

in the last few months
with the COVID-zero policy.

So a lot of businessmen
have not been

able to go there for
the last two years,

and now with COVID-zero
and lockdowns

and the unpredictability, it's
forcing everybody to rethink.

It's like, what does my
manufacturing footprint
need to look like?

So as you say, I
think we're going

to see a push towards
more regionalization.

With that will probably
come more cost.

A lot of people are
also thinking about,

I've got to have
multiple suppliers

so I don't get caught short
with only one supplier again.

So there's a lot of
rethinking and a lot
of moving parts right now.
Yeah.

So one more question for you
before I let you go, Willy.

And that would be, if we've got
people who are watching this

who are leaders of supply
chain-dependent businesses,

any words of advice for
what they should be thinking
about in the near-term?

Number one thing they
should think about

is visibility, which
means understanding where

your dependencies are
and getting closer

to on-the-ground
visibility of where
those things are happening.

So for example, a number of
companies over the last two

years have done much
better than others

because they've
been on the ground

and been able to see
things coming up.

So for example, I was
in China the first two

weeks of January 2020, so I
could see COVID-19 coming.

And understanding how
manufacturing is done in China

and understanding how the
shipping of logistics is done,

I could see the wave of
troubles coming with that delay,
with normal transit delays.

And so if you have
that visibility

into what's happening
on the ground,

it'll give you a
little more head

start on adjusting to some
of the disruptions that
are coming.

So I think visibility
is really a key thing.

I know it's really a struggle,
especially for seaborne cargo,
less so for airborne cargo.

And a lot of startups
that are working

to improve visibility there,
but that's the number one thing.

Really understanding where your
goods are and how they move,

and that will help you a
lot more, because then when

you see situations breaking
on the ground, then

you can understand how the
whole system will react
and what you should do.

Professor Willy Shih, thanks so
much for sharing your insights
on managing through crisis.
Thanks for having me.
